content:
Sure, here are a few more sub-styles within each of the fine art styles mentioned in your previous question:

1. Greco-Roman art:
	* Attic, Cycladic, Archaic, Classical, Hellenistic
2. Byzantine art:
	* Cretan School, Macedonian School, Palaiologan Renaissance
3. Romanesque art:
	* Saxon, Norman-Sicilian, Lombard-Emilian
4. Pop Art:
	* American Pop, British Pop, European Pop, Japanese Pop, Australian Pop
5. Minimalism:
	* Minimalist Sculpture, Minimalist Painting, Minimalist Architecture, Minimalist Design
6. Abstract Expressionism:
	* New York School, San Francisco School, Washington Color School, Helen Frankenthaler, Franz Kline
7. Indigenous Art (various styles from Indigenous cultures around the world):
	* Native American Plains, Native American Southwest, Native American Woodlands, Inuit Sculpture, Pacific Northwest Coast
8. African Art (including traditional and contemporary styles):
	* Dogon Mask, Yoruba Textile, Bantu Pottery, Ndebele Beadwork, Ashanti Gold
9. Oceanic Art (including traditional and contemporary styles from Pacific Islands):
	* Maori Tattoo, Hawaiian Quilt, Samoan Tapa, Tongan Mat, Fijian Dagger
10. Pre-Columbian Art (from indigenous cultures in the Americas before European contact):
* Maya Sculpture, Aztec Calendar, Inca Textile, Moche Ceramic, Nazca Line
11. Islamic Art (including calligraphy, architecture, and decorative arts):
* Ottoman Tiles, Persian Miniature, Mughal Miniature, Timurid Architecture, Fatimid Rock crystal

Again, these are not exhaustive lists, but they give you a good idea of the various sub-styles that exist within each fine art style.
